div.p:
Copy of R L E's letter to Hunter
Dear Sir Some Comic Dramas sometimes inculcate
useful lessons - for instance "Three weeks after
marriage" pointed out to me so strongly the folly
of explanations and recriminations that I have
avoided them not only with my wife but
with my friends - I shall therefore say no
more about your misapprehension with res-
-pect respect to the time of your publishing Ormond
except to point out that I from time to time told you
the manuscript would be shortly sent to you
And that I distinctly told you that Maria had
written 1200 pages in three months. Could it be
supposed she worked so hard, deprived herself
of all amusement and hazarded her health
for the purpose of having a manuscript in Mr.
Briars hands for six months before it was to be
published?

We are however perfectly satisfied that this
was only a dull misapprehension on your
part and that you did not mean to treat
Maria as a hireling. We entirely accede
to Captain Beauforts arrangements -viz - that
the printer shall work double tides. Indeed it
will be as much your interest as it is our
pleasure that you should hasten the printing

I shall now answer your former letter
relative to our money transactions.
In the first place I reiterate for the third time my request
that the small account which exists between us
may be sent to use - We have ordered books and var-
rious various articles and these small matter should not be
mixed with a large account.

Secondly the time of payment of Comic Dramas not
having been mentioned between us we shall state to
be the seventh of next may - being a year after pub-
-lication publication

Thirdl - With respect to the three volumes of tales
I propose that one third should be paid at the expi-
-ration expiration of six months after its publication - Another
third at the expiration of a year - and the remain
-der remainder at the expiration of a year and a half -
I think these payments will press more lightly upon
you than the disbursement of a large sum at one
time. But if you prefer paying the whole at the end
of one year we shall most willingly agree to that ar-
rangement.arrangement

Fourthly I will defray the expense of cancelling the
two sheet Harrington which were at my desire
improvidently cut off from the first volume

Fifthly We desire that ten guineas may be given
to Mr. Churchill when the tales are finished.

We thank you for your handsome &
manly letter. And I do assure you that I am as
little disposed to take offence, as you can be to give it
div.closer:
I am dear Sir, your Obedr. Servant
R. L. Edgeworth
-

postscript.p: You have not sent us Mr. Webbe's music

And now my dear Francis accept
Maria's own heartfelt thanks - you have by the
admirably able hand & successful manner in
which you have managed this business relieved
me from a state of anxiety which I can describe to
you only by saying that you have taken my mind
off the rack - And now I feel & thank you for the
delight of seeing my father perfectly satisfied & happy
& all smooth again with poor Hunter - my father
when I requested to add a line from myself to his letter
to Hunter desired that I should not do so. - Indeed I for-
bear forbear with the less reluctance because I am so convinced
of the mischief I have done & the misapprehension I
created in Hunters mind by the foolish note I wrote
about Harrington - However good the intentions with
which it was written it has I see done mischief and
I will interfere no more - You may conceive what
I should have suffered if I had been the cause of a total
break up with a person who was doing all he could
to oblige me - From this you have saved me & I
leave it to you to judge how much I feel obliged
Maria Edgeworth

My dear Francis after all the Compliments you have received
from these distinguished authors what can my mite of praise be
worth - ? But I must have the satisfaction of saying that you have
managed the Hunterian controversy perfectly- and that you have done the
very thing I not only wished but expected. Telling dear Alicia that
she shall hear from me by the twopenny post - and in the mean time
thank her for her very cheerful and pleasant letter and give her my love
Your Karamania is beautifull - tho' the plates are not as delicate as on the Indian paper F E.
Maria is quite charmed with what
Alicia says of the little dramas - it is
just what she wished but did not dare
to hope to hear from her readers - We
are all curious to know which is liked
by who - which by she & which by you
